name: Matthew Stanciu
title: Matthew Stanciu
description: A 20-year-old high school maker from West Lafayette, IN

repos.name: Purdue Hackers Events
repos.desc: A website for Purdue students to view & get an email reminder for upcoming Purdue Hackers events.

repos.name: Hack Club Meetings
repos.desc: Hack Club meeting recordings and interactive articles to help new club leaders run great club meetings.

repos.name: Scrappy
repos.desc: The Slack bot that powers Scrapbook, Hack Club's social network for sharing daily project updates.

repos.name: Apple Music Slack Status
repos.desc: A Slack app that sets your status to the current song from Apple Music.

repos.name: colors.zephyr
repos.desc: Made on The Hacker Zephyr, a collaborative pixel drawing canvas for fellow hackers aboard the train.

repos.name: Music Timer
repos.desc: A web app that displays a timer next to the currently-playing song, for presenting technical workshops.

projects.name: The Hacker Zephyr
projects.desc: Summer 2021, I helped organize a hackathon on a chartered train across the US, from Burlington, Vermont to Los Angeles, California. Over 10 days, 42 high schoolers built hundreds of mini projects on a local intranet as we traveled 3,502 miles across the country.

projects.name: Hack Club
projects.desc: I graduated high school a semester early in December 2019 & took a gap year before college to work for Hack Club, a nonprofit that helps high schoolers start coding clubs. I worked out of Burlington, VT until June 2021 as the head of the clubs program, introducing new curriculum & a new leader guide, & helping students run awesome coding clubs.

projects.name: Windy City Hacks
projects.desc: On June 22-23, 2019, I ran Windy City Hacks, a 24-hour high school hackathon in Chicago. I spent 4 months leading a team of 7 to organize this event, raising a total of $14k and garnering 320 signups (160 of which attended).

projects.name: West Lafayette Hack Club
projects.desc: I led a Hack Club at my high school for 2 and a half years. Meetings ran like mini-hackathons, where students learn to code by hacking on their own projects. It became a go-to place for students at my high school to explore coding in a fun, engaging way, & helped me grow tremendously as a leader.

projects.name: Hack Pennsylvania
projects.desc: On January 19-20, 2019, I helped organize Pennsylvania's largest high school hackathon in State College, PA. After 3 months of organizing, we raised $15k and garnered 207 signups (111 of which attended).

projects.name: CodeDay Indianapolis
projects.desc: In August 2018, I started CodeDay Indianapolis, which ran for the first time in November 2018 and for the second time in February 2019. Though small (15-20 attendees), it was the first event of its kind ever organized in Indiana.
